cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTYS GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. November 1941.SECRET.W.M. (41)109th Conclusions.Copy No.TO BE KEPT, UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 109 (41).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W.1, on Wednesday, November 5, 1941, at 12-15 p.m.Present:The Right Hon Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon. Ernest Bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and NationalService.The following were also present:The Right Hon. Sir Earle Page,Special Envoy from the Governmentof the Commonwealth of Australia(Items 2-3).The Right Hon. Herbert Morrison,M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The Right Hon. Lord Moyne, Secre-tary of State for the Colonies.Captain the Right Hon. H. D.Margesson, M.P., Secretary of Statefor War.The Right Hon. Brendan Bracken,M.P., Minister of Information.Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff.The Right Hon. Viscount Cranborne,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs.The Right Hon. A. V. Alexander,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.The Hon. Sir Alexander Cadogan,Permanent Under-Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs.General Sir John Dill, Chief of theImperial General Staff.Air Chief Marshal Sir Charles F. A.Portal, Chief of the Air Staff.Secretariat.Sir Edward Bridges.Major-General Sir Hastings Ismay.Mr. L. F. Burgis.[23116] WAR CABINET 109 (41).Contents.minute no. Subject. page 1 Parliament .... .... .... .... .... .... .... 129The King's Speeches on the Prorogation and Opening ofParliament.2 The Par East........ ....... ............ 1293 Naval, Military and Air Operations ............ 129Air Operations.Naval Operations:Shipping losses.Military Operations:U.S.S.R. Parliament.The King'speeches on the prorogation and opening ofParliament.(previous reference erence:W.M. (41) 103rdConclusions,Minute 2.)The Far East.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 108thConclusions,Minute 5.)Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 108thConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.1. The War Cabinet had before them copies of drafts of TheKing's Speeches, submitted by the Committee appointed by the WarCabinet on the 16th October (W.P. (G) (41) 126).The War Cabinet-Approved the drafts of the Speeches, subject to the amend-ments set out in the schedule annexed to these Minutes.2. The War Cabinet had a further discussion on this matter,which is recorded in the Secretary's Standard File of War cabinet conclusions.naval operations.Shipping Losses.MilitaryOperations.U.S.S.R.3. The Chiefs of Staff gave the following information in amplification of Cabinet War Room Records Nos. 793-794 : *Summary of aircraft losses since the 3rd November : Home Theatre Enemy 1 destroyed.2 probable.3 damaged.Our Own *2 Fighters.2 Coastal Command Aircraft.Overseas Theatre Enemy 5 destroyed.12 probable.2 damaged.Our Own 4 destroyed.1 damaged.A promising attack on an enemy submarine had been made onthe previous day. Two enemy merchant ships, one of 7,000-10,000 tons and another of 5,000-6,000 tons, had been bombed andhit in the North Sea. .During the previous two days 34,000 tons of shipping had been sunk. This figure included five ships attacked in a homeward-bound convoy East of Belle Isle Straits.In the Finnish, Leningrad and Kalinin sectors there had been little change, although fierce fighting continued at Kalinin. Therehad been no further advance on the Moscow front, but reports hadbeen received that the Germans were about to launch a new offensive.In the Ukraine there had been a pause, but new operations mightbe expected to begin again shortly. In the Crimea the Germans had reached Feodosia. The Germans had been carrying out photo-graphic reconnaissances of the area North of the Caucasus Range.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Great George Street, S.W. 1,November 5, 1941. ANNEX.Speech on the Prorogation of Parliament.Paragraph 5. The first two and a half lines should read as follows : " My Navy has continued to attack the enemy wherever it has beenable to find him. Aided by its Auxiliaries and the Fishing Fleet, it hasmaintained . . . ."Paragraph 6. This should read as follows . " The position of My Forces in the Middle East has been greatly strengthened. The brilliant campaigns in East Africa, where the enemy,despite great numerical superiority, were evicted from the mountain fast-nesses of Eritrea and Ethiopia and either destroyed or captured, prove theskill of My Commanders and the endurance of My Forces from many partsof the Empire. These operations, which augur well for the future, were rendered possible by the annihilation last winter of the hostile army which sought to invade Egypt from Cyrenaica."A new paragraph should be inserted on the achievements of the Royal Air Forcein the last year.Paragraph 7, last line. For " that area " read " those regions."Paragraph 8. Delete the sentence referring to the Premier of Burma.Paragraph 9. The Chancellor of the Exchequer was asked to suggest a fewwords which could be inserted about the relief afforded by the War Damage Actto sufferers from air raids. 'Speech on the Opening of Parliament.Paragraph 2. The last line should read : " the needs of the Soviet Union in its heroic conflict."Paragraph 3 should read : " The United States are furnishing My Peoples and My Allies with war supplies of all kinds on a scale unexampled in history."Paragraph 4t should read : " My relations with Turkey, with whom I have a valued treaty of alliance, remain firmly based on trust and friendship."Paragraph 5 should read as follows : " I welcome the restoration to His Throne of His Majesty the emperor of Ethiopia. Thus, the first country which fell a victim to aggression hasbeen the first to be liberated and re-established."Paragraph 6 should read as follows: " My loyal subjects in Malta continue to face air-attack with a fortitudethat commands My deepest admiration."Paragraph 8 should read as follows : " The fulfilment of the task to which we are committed will call for theunsparing effort of every one of us. I am confident that My People will answerthis call with the courage and devotion which our forefathers never failedto show when our country was in danger."
